title: I have lost all my bookmarks and settings
content:
I have a Firefox account and after reinstalling the Mozilla Firefox web browser and logging into my account I have lost all my bookmarks and settings. I don't know what the problem was or how to solve it, but it seems like a very big mistake to me. That has never happened to me with Chrome. I have tried to do everything they say in the help, including the Profile Manager, but I can't recover my settings.

I need urgent help with this problem or I will stop using this browser.

All the best Ricardo Sandoval Pérez
creator: r.sandovalperez

title: firefox installation
content:
For many years a happy user. (handicapped with shattered wrist, may be typos.)

My mac spontaneously crashed and rebooted overnight, a rare event. When I came up firefox wouldn't work.

Many, many times I clear out all vestiges of firefox from downloads, applications and every place I can think of.

I then empty trash and I use safari (ugh) to reinstall firefox. Everything proceeds well. When I activate the newly installed firefox application, nothing happens. Eventually in the "Force Quit Applications" it says Firefox "not responding"

I cannot think of anything else to try. Everything else on the Mac seems to be functioning well. The os is 12.7

The support archives do not have a case like this—0 responses

What
creator: koepsel

title: Government Gateway login issues
content: I have several profiles for logging into HMRC's Government Gateway to access my HMRC services. I can log in with my Username and Password but when I enter the Access Code (sent to my mobile) the website goes back to the login page, it won't let me in. If I do the same on Microsoft Edge, there is no issue and I can login without any problems. I tried the 'Forget about this website' fix and also cleared the cache in Firefox. I will not delete all my cookies as they are vital for all my access to financial and government website access. Some profiles (different Username) will let me in (for certain Government Services) but others won't. It is not an issue with HMRC as Microsoft Edge seems to work. Can anyone provide a solution to this issue or have also experienced this issue? Thanks. René

title: Unwanted "Manage Password" suggestions in Special:UserRights on MediaWiki sites
content:
Hi everyone,

I'm encountering an issue specifically on MediaWiki sites, like this one, where the "Special:UserRights" page behaves strangely. Whenever I try to type in the input area, the browser suggests "Manage Password" even though it's not a relevant action on this page.

I'm using Firefox 123.00 and this happens on both my Linux (Ubuntu 22.04) and Windows 11 OS. I don't have any password manager extensions installed.

While this might seem like a minor inconvenience, it's quite disruptive to the workflow when managing user rights on MediaWiki sites.

Has anyone else experienced this issue? Is there a known solution or workaround to prevent the "Manage Password" suggestion from appearing on the "Special:UserRights" page?

Thanks in advance for any help!
creator: khattab4543

title: Any way to get lost pages back?
content: Firefox updated last night (March 2, sometime in the evening). When I finally was able to reopen it, it had gone back to a much older saved bunch of tabs. I had a very crazy day, and had multiple tabs open when I left, that I meant to go back to and finish up with, now they are gone and I can't remember them all. There were also tabs that I know I closed quite a while ago, so it really went back in time. Is there any way to get those tabs from yesterday back? They are not in History under "recently closed," I suppose because Firefox went back to a MUCH older set of things, so it doesn't "remember" them as "closed," because it doesn't "remember" them at all?

title: Mouse won't highlight text properly
content:
Highlighting with the mouse is full of glitches. It never works right. It either stops highlighting or highlights opposite the direction I'm moving the mouse.

I need to summarize a recent medical encounter; the hospital's 234 pages are out of temporal order and have many repeats. I want to put it in time order and delete the repeats. It's a PDF, and since I can't use Acrobat anymore, I read PDFs in Firefox.

Not once have I been able to mark a section of text properly. There seem to be some forbidden areas: I highlight what I can, transfer it, then go back for the rest, but it won't highlight.

Ctl-A highlights it. I often do that and delete the excess, but that's inconvenient.

I can open the same file in xpdf and mark without trouble, but I don't like xpdf.

For this doc, I converted the PDF to text with pdf2text, but it's harder to read. I identify target text in Firefox, then find it in the text version, use emacs to copy from the original to my summary.

I've tried a fresh battery in the mouse. Every other app works.
creator: RandomTroll

title: How do I get Firefox to append www. and .com to my URL inputs?
content:
For years I've been able to input a website keyword (let's say "cnn" like in an old report I ran across) and the "www." and ".com" portions would be added without my typing them. Some time ago, this started to fail. Why?

I tried about:config changes that were said to work with the old "cnn" problem report but nothing helps for me.

Also, I use the local Windows Hosts file to give my router a quick reference name to get into it. That too has worked for years but began to fail last year. Inconvenient. The best I could track this down, it has something to do with forced DNS lookups and skipping the old Hosts file. If so, any work around to get my system simplicity back?

Help is appreciated. I liked the challenge of computer geekdom 30 years ago but I'm getting too old for this, well, you know the old saying.
